page.title: 4.9.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will deepen your understanding of functions by comparing representations of several functions relating the same pair of quantities. You will also analyze two or more graphs simultaneously, interpreting their relative features and their average rates of change in context.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Compare the features of graphs of functions and explain what they mean in the situations represented.
  • Make sense of an equation of the form \(f(x)=g(x)\) in terms of a situation and a graph, and know how to find the solutions.
  • Explain statements about two or more functions when they are written in function notation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.9.1: Analyzing Graphs and Statements in Function Notation
  • 4.9.2: Interpreting Graphs and Statements in Terms of a Situation
  • 4.9.2: Self Check
  • 4.9.3: Comparing Functions Represented in Separate Graphs
  • 4.9.3: Self Check
  • 4.9.4: Compare Graphs and Statements that Represent Functions without a Context
  • 4.9.4: Self Check
  • 4.9.5: Analyzing Functions Using Real-World Context

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.9.6: Practice
  • 4.9.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 4.9.1: Analyzing Graphs and Statements in Function Notation
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

This graph shows the populations of Baltimore and Cleveland in the 20th century. \(B(t)\) is the population of Baltimore in year t. \(C(t)\) is the population of Cleveland in year \(t\).



  1. Estimate \(B(1930)\) and explain what it means in this situation.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(B(1930)\) is about 800,000. It’s the population of Baltimore in 1930.



  1. Here are pairs of statements about the two populations. In each pair, which statement is true? Be prepared to explain how you know.

    1. \(B(2000)>C(2000)\) or \(B(2000)<C(2000)\)

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\(B(2000)>C(2000)\)



    1. \( B(1900)=C(1900)\) or \(B(1900)>C(1900)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(B(1900)>C(1900)\)



  1. Were the two cities’ populations ever the same? If so, when?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes. The populations were the same in roughly 1910 and 1943.

page.title: 4.9.2: Interpreting Graphs and Statements in Terms of a Situation
page.contents:
Activity

\(H(t)\) is the percentage of homes in the United States that have a landline phone in year \(t\). \(C(t)\) is the percentage of homes with only a cell phone. Here are the graphs of \(H\) and \(C\).



  1. Estimate \(H(2006)\) and \(C(2006)\). Explain what each value tells us about the phones.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(H(2006)\) is about 85, and \(C(2006)\) is about 14. In 2006, 85% of homes had a landline phone, and 14% of homes had only a cell phone.



  1. What is the approximate solution to \(C(t)=20\)? Explain what the solution means in this situation.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Approximately 2008. It means that around 2008, 20% of homes used only cell phones.



  1. Determine if each equation is true. Be prepared to explain how you know.

    1. \(C(2011)=H(2011)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, because \(C(2011)\) is about 30 and \(H(2011)\) is about 70. The percentage of homes with a landline phone and the percentage of homes with only a cell phone were not equal.



    1. \(C(2015)=H(2015)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes, because in 2015 the percentage of homes with a landline and the percentage of homes with only a cell phone were equal, as shown by the intersection of the graphs.



  1.    
    1. Between 2004 and 2015, did the percentage of homes with landlines decrease at the same rate at which the percentage of cell-phones-only homes increased?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, the percentage of cell-phones-only homes increased at a rate close to that by which the percentage of landline-owning homes decreased, but not exactly the same.



    1. Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • In 2004, only about 6% of homes had only cell phones. In 2015, about 48% did. The average rate of change for \(C\) is \(\frac{48-6}{2015-2004}=\frac{42}{11}\), or about 3.8. This means the percentage of homes relying only on cell phones grew by about 3.8% each year.
  • In 2004, about 92% of homes had a landline. In 2015, only about 48% did. The average rate of change for \(H\) is \(\frac{48-92}{2015-2004}=\frac{-44}{11}\), or –4. This means the percentage of homes that used landlines fell by 4% each year.


Extending Your Thinking

  1. Explain why the statement \(C(t)+H(t)\leq100\) is true in this situation. Enter your answer here:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Each household either has a landline or has no landline and relies only on cell phones, so \(H(t)\) and \(C(t)\) calculate separate groups of people. As long as there are not rounding errors, \(H(t)\) and \(C(t)\) together can only be 100 percent, and it will be less if there are people with no phone service at all.


  1. What value does \(C(t)+H(t)\) appear to take between 2004 and 2017? How much does this value vary in that interval?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It appears to take a value a little less than 100, maybe close to 97. For example, the two graphs meet below the midway point (50). At the beginning and the end of the shown interval, they add up to a little less than 100 as well. The sum is not constant (the shapes of the two graphs are different) but does not vary much, so the percentage of people with no phone service is small for the entire period.

page.title: 4.9.2: Self Check
page.contents: A Mars rover collected the following temperature data over 1.6 Martian days. A Martian day is called a Sol. Which of the following is true about the comparison between ground temperature and air temperature?

answer.answer_text: At 11 Sols, the ground temperature is warmer than the air temperature.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The ground temperature’s graph is below that of the air temperature at this time. The answer is at 11 Sols, the air temperature is warmer than the ground temperature.

answer.answer_text: The ground temperature is always warmer than the air temperature.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Throughout the temperature collection, the ground and air temperatures change which is greater than the other. The answer is at 11 Sols, the air temperature is warmer than the ground temperature.

answer.answer_text: At 11 Sols, the air temperature is warmer than the ground temperature.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The graph of the air temperature is above the graph of the ground temperature at the place where the \(x\)-axis is 11 Sols.

answer.answer_text: The air temperature is always warmer than the ground temperature.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Throughout the temperature collection, the ground and air temperatures change which is greater than the other. The answer is at 11 Sols, the air temperature is warmer than the ground temperature.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.9.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Comparing Populations

Graphs are very useful for comparing two or more functions. Here are graphs of functions \(C\) and \(T\), which give the populations (in millions) of California and Texas in year \(x\).


What can we tell about the populations?

How can we tell?

How can we convey this with function notation?

In the early 1900s, California had a smaller population than Texas.

The graph of \(C\) is below the graph of \(T\) when \(x\) is 1900.

\(C(1900)<T(1900)\)

Around 1935, the two states had the same population of about 5 million people.

The graphs intersect at about \((1935, 5)\).

\(C(1935)=5\) and
\(T(1935)=5\), and
\(C(1935)=T(1935)\)

After 1935, California has had more people than Texas.

When \(x\) is greater than 1935, the graph of \(C(x)\) is above that of \(T(x)\).

\(C(x)>T(x)\) for
\(x>1935\)

Both populations have increased over time, with no periods of decline.

Both graphs slant upward from left to right.

From 1900 to 2010, the population of California has risen faster than that of Texas. California had a greater average rate of change.

If we draw a line to connect the points for 1900 and 2010 on each graph, the line for \(C\) has a greater slope than that for \(T\).

\(\frac{C(2010)-C(1900)}{201-1900}>\frac{T(2010)-T(1900)}{2010-1900}\)

Try It: Comparing Populations


Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course.



Which state had a greater population in 1920?

Select the Solution button to check your work.

Your answer may vary, but here is an example:

Here is how to read the graph to find the larger population:

On the horizontal axis, at 1920, the graph for Texas touches at about 5 million, while the graph for California touches at about 4 million.

In 1920, Texas had a larger population than California.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.9.3: Comparing Functions Represented in Separate Graphs
page.contents:
Activity

The number of people who watched a TV episode is a function of that show’s episode number. Here are three graphs of three functions—\(A\), \(B\), and \(C\)—representing three different TV shows.

Show A

Show B

Show C



  1. Match each description with a graph that could represent the situation described. One of the descriptions has no corresponding graph.

    1. This show has a good core audience. It had a guest star in the fifth episode that brought in some new viewers, but most of them stopped watching after that.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

graph of function \(C\)



    1. This show is one of the most popular shows, and its audience keeps increasing.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

no match



    1. This show has a small audience, but it’s improving, so more people are noticing.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

graph of function \(A\)



    1. This show started out huge. Even though it feels like it crashed, it still has more viewers than another show.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

graph of function \(B\)



  1. Which is greatest, \(A(7)\), \(B(7)\), or \(C(7)\)? Explain what the answer tells us about the shows.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(B(7)\). 3.6 million people watched the 7th episode of Show B.




    1. Sketch a graph of the viewership of the fourth TV show that did not have a matching graph.

Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. Then select the Solution button to check your work:

Compare your answer:


Video: Comparing Functions Represented in Separate Graphs

Watch the following video to learn more about how to compare functions that are represented in separate graphs.

page.title: 4.9.3: Self Check
page.contents: For which of the following functions is \(f(3)\) the greatest value?

answer.response:
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The value of \(f(3)\) is approximately 9. The answer is

where \(f(3)\) is approximately 23.
That’s correct! Check yourself: \(f(3)\) equals approximately 23.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The value of \(f(3)\) is approximately 3.6. The answer is

where \(f(3)\) is approximately 23.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The value of \(f(3)\) is approximately 0.2. The answer is

where \(f(3)\) is approximately 23.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.9.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Comparing Real-Life Functions

Two people, Adam and Bianca, are competing to see who can save more money in one month. Use the table and the graph below to determine who will save more money at the end of the month. State how much money each person had at the start of the competition. (Assume each is following a linear function in his or her saving habit.) Let Adam’s function be represented by \(A(t)\), where \(t\) is days, and Bianca’s function be represented by \(B(t)\).


Which is greater, \(A(2)\) or \(B(2)\)? Explain what this answer means.

\(A(2)=9\) and \(B(2)=8\), so after 2 days, Adam has saved more money.

Try It: Comparing Real-Life Functions

Aleph is running at a constant rate on a flat, paved road. The graph below, \(A(t)\), represents the total distance, \(A\), he covers with respect to time, \(t\).

Shannon is running on a flat, rocky trail that eventually rises up a steep mountain. The graph below, \(S(t)\), represents the total distance, \(S\), she covers with respect to time, \(t\).


Who has traveled farther after 40 minutes? Explain your answer.

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to determine who went a greater distance:

Aleph traveled farther in 40 minutes. Comparing the graphs, \(A(40)\) is 5.5 miles, and \(S(40)\) is approximately 2.5 miles.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.9.4: Comparing Graphs and Statements that Represent Functions without a Context
page.contents:
Activity

Here are graphs that represent two functions, \(f\) and \(g\).



  1. Decide which function value is greater for each given input. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

    1. \(f(2)\) or \(g(2)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(g(2)\) is greater.



    1. \(f(4)\) or \(g(4)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

They appear to be equal.



    1. \(f(6)\) or \(g(6)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(f(6)\) is greater.



    1. \(f(8)\) or \(g(8)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(f(8)\) is greater.



  1. Is there a value of \(x\) at which the equation \(f(x)=g(x)\) is true? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Yes. Sample reasoning: If the graphs intersect when \(x\) is 4 and when it is 9, then \(f(4)=g(4)\) and \(f(9)=g(9)\).



  1. Identify at least two values of \(x\) at which the inequality \(f(x)<g(x)\) is true.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

1, 3, 10, 11, or other \(x\)-values that are less than 4 and greater than 9

page.title: 4.9.4: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following is true about the graphs of \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\) below?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The graph of \(g\) is higher than the graph of \(f\) at \(x=0\). The answer is \(f(1)=g(1)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: When \(x=1\), both \(f\) and \(g\) equal –3.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: At \(x = -3\), \(f\) is higher than \(g\). The answer is \(f(1)=g(1)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: At \(x =-1\), \(g\) is greater than \(f\). The answer is \(f(1)=g(1)\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.9.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Using Graphs to Find Values

Two functions, \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\), are graphed below.

What is the value of \(f(-1)\)?

Look at where \(x=-1\) touches the graph of \(f\). The \(y\)-value is –3.

\(f(-1)=-3\)

What is the value of \(g(-1)\)?

Look where \(x=-1\) touches the graph of \(g\). The \(y\)-value is –1.

\(g(-1)=-1\)

Which value is greater?

\(g(-1)>f(-1)\)

Try It: Using Graphs to Find Values

Two functions, \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\), are graphed below.

Which is greater, \(f(1)\) or \(g(1)\)?

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to determine which value is greater:

Looking at the graph, \(f(1)\) is where \(x=1\) reaches the graph of \(f(x)\). The \(y\)-value there is 4. So, \(f(1)=4\).

Similarly, \(g(1)\) is where \(x=1\) reaches the graph of \(g(x)\). The \(y\)-value there is 2.

So, \(f(1) >g(1)\).

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.9.5: Analyzing Functions Using Real-World Context
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Functions \(R\) and \(D\) give the height, in feet, of a toy rocket and a drone, \(t\) seconds after they are released. Here are the graphs of \(R\) (for the rocket) and \(D\) (for the drone).


  1. Which of the inequalities is true: \(R(2)>D(2)\) or \(D(2)> R(2)\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(R(2)>D(2)\)



  1. What was the height of the drone when the toy rocket hit the ground?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

20 feet



  1. For what value of \(t\) is \(R(t)=D(t)\) true? What does this tell you about the drone and the toy rocket?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

About \(t=4.5\). After 4.5 seconds, the toy rocket and the drone are at the same height.

page.title: 4.9.6 Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Functions \(R\) and \(D\) give the height, in feet, of a toy rocket and a drone, \(t\) seconds after they are released.

Here are the graphs of \(R\) (for the rocket) and \(D\) (for the drone).

  1. Decide whether the following statements are true or false.
    1. \(R(3)>D(3)\)

Correct! True

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is true. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(R(0)=D(0)\)

Correct! False

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is false. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(R(4)=D(4)\)

Correct! True

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is true. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(R(0)=D(0)+25\)

Correct! True

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is true. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \((7)>R(5)\)

Correct! False

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is false. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(A(t)\) is the average high temperature in Aspen, Colorado, \(t\) months after the start of the year. \(M(t)\) is the average high temperature in Minneapolis, Minnesota, \(t\) months after the start of the year. Temperature is measured in degrees Fahrenheit.

    2. Which function had the higher average rate of change between the beginning of January and middle of March?

Correct! Minneapolis

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Minneapolis. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Here are two graphs representing functions \(f\) and \(g\).
    Select all statements that are true about functions \(f\) and \(g\).

Correct! There are values of \(x\) where \(f(x)=g(x)\), \(f(-1)<g(-1)\), and \(f(-3)>g(4)\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: There are values of \(x\) where \(f(x)=g(x)\), \(f(-1)<g(-1)\), and \(f(-3)>g(4)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 4–6, use the three graphs below:

The three graphs represent the progress of three runners in a 400-meter race.

The solid line represents Runner A. The dotted line represents Runner B. The dashed line represents Runner C.

  1. Which runner ran at a constant rate throughout the race?

Correct! Runner C

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Runner C. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which runner stopped running for a while?

Correct! Runner A

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Runner A. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which runner won the race?

Correct! Runner C

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Runner C. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the graphs below for questions 7–8.

Show A                                             Show B                                   Show C

  1. Which show had the largest audience for episode 4?

Correct! Show B

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.9.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Show B. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which show had the largest audience for their first episode?

Correct! Show B

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.9.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Show B. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 4.9.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Compare the features of graphs of functions and explain what they mean in the situations represented.
  • Make sense of an equation of the form \(f(x)=g(x)\) in terms of a situation and a graph, and know how to find the solutions.
  • Explain statements about two or more functions when they are written in function notation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.9.1: Analyzing Graphs and Statements in Function Notation
    • In this activity, you used function notation to find specific values on the graph and compare the two functions. You had to estimate the values of functions and determine where the graphs were the same in the context of the problem.
  • 4.9.2: Interpreting Graphs and Statements in Terms of a Situation
    • In this activity, more emphasis was placed on the meaning of function notation and what its solution represented. You also used function notation to do calculations.
    • 4.9.2: Self Check
  • 4.9.3: Comparing Functions Represented in Separate Graphs
    • In this activity, you compared the size of the audience per episode of three different TV shows. It was important to notice and analyze the units of each axis before you could compare the three different graphs. You realized that just looking at the shape of the graph can be deceiving, and exact (or at least approximate) data points are better for comparisons.
    • 4.9.3: Self Check
  • 4.9.4: Compare Graphs and Statements that Represent Functions without a Context
    • In this activity, you used a graph with two functions to compare values.
    • 4.9.4: Self Check
  • 4.9.5: Analyzing Functions Using Real-World Context
    • In this activity, you compared the heights of a toy rocket and a drone in a real-life context.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.9.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
